Speaker: written by
Dialogue: John Fusco

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Hey. Nice tie.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Don't get too attached.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Ya got the paper?

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You're my hero, Carl.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Heroes ain't supposed to shake. I'm shakin', man, look at me.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Breathe, Carl. Four, nice, deep ones.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Anyone stops us going in, we're with the Bowen-Hamilton Textile Company. We have rug samples.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Rug samples.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: We are one-dimensional, boring peddlers of fine carpet, Carl.

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: Hey, look who's here.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Louis, my man, what's happenin'?

Speaker: fence man
Dialogue: Clean ones?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Immaculate.

Speaker: fence man
Dialogue: What ya got there, seventy-five thousand?

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: A hundred and ten. Count it.

Speaker: fence man
Dialogue: SALLLLY!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: F.B.I.! Get your face on the fuckin' floor! MOVE!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Slam dunk.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Beauty. Beauty...

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Jesus Christ, Larry, what the fu-- Larry. That's not even your name, is it? What's your real name, you fucking scumbag?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Don't have one, Carl. I have a number, man. Just like the numbers on those treasury checks. You stole from your own country, Carl. Shame on you.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Sugar Ray.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: They want ya Home. Upstairs wants to see ya.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Make sure ya spell my name right.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: He had dinner at my mother's.

Speaker: intercom
Dialogue: SA Levoi, Sir.

Speaker: tully
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: tully
Dialogue: Ray...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Mister Tully.

Speaker: tully
Dialogue: Do you want a coffee?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: No. No, no. Thank you.

Speaker: tully
Dialogue: Levoi, Cooch. Raymond Levoi, Criminal Division.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Oh, yeah -- right.

Speaker: tully
Dialogue: Ray this is --

Speaker: tully
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: couture
Dialogue: Hello, Ray.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: It's an honor.

Speaker: tully
Dialogue: Ray, we're taking you off the street. We need you out in South Dakota.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: South Dakota...  Did I do something unsatisfactory, Sir?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: No, Ray. You're gonna have to blame that on your grandmother.

Speaker: tully
Dialogue: Interesting bloodline you have, Ray.  French, Scots-Irish, Italian, ...and one-eighth American Indian.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Sioux Indian, right?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I'm not that sure. Yeah, I think --

Speaker: tully
Dialogue: -- yes, Teton Sioux. Father's side.

Speaker: tully
Dialogue: Ray, there's been a homicide out in an area known as The Badlands. Indian Reservation.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: It's not the first. There's been several. And our field office in Rapid City is getting a lot of heat... none of the investigations have turned up jack shit.

Speaker: tully
Dialogue: The main problem is, Ray, these people are extremely distrustful of outsiders, non-Indians. Relations have not been amicable.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Different culture. Hard to penetrate. The Indians don't like white cops poking around. And that's why we're in a position where we have to bring in an American Indian agent.

Speaker: tully
Dialogue: With an Indian representative out there, we hope to keep hostilities dormant; this is a COINTELPRO, Selective Operations Unit, and it'll be easier on Agent Couture if you can gain the people's trust and maybe --

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Woh, excuse me, Sir... I see what you're saying... I've got a little Indian blood, that's true. But --  I am not an... an Indian. I can't just go in and --

Speaker: tully
Dialogue: -- your father was part Sioux.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I didn't know him, Sir. He passed away when I was six.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Seven.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Don't worry about it, Ray. As long as the people have proof that we sent them one of their own, no one's gonna ask you to weave baskets or make it rain.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Eight murders in less than a year. All of them Indian. All of them unsolved. Is the law a non-entity out here or what?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Those are two agents who went into a reservation a few years ago to serve a warrant. They were executed at close range. That one there is a police officer killed by the Mohawks up in Canada more recently.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Jesus...

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: The agents who have worked out here say its like going into Nam. Unfamiliar terrain, foreign language, foreign customs... and you never know when you might walk into a few rounds. They hold a lot of old anger for the white man out here.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Were you in Nam?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Airborne. That's where they used to get us agents from. Now we get 'em from Carnegie-Melon, Ivy League. Accountants and computer whiz-kids. Yuppies with guns.  That's scary shit.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Not as scary as a Hoover man with a computer.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Hey, hey, hey. J. Edgar would've loved you. He'd love anybody who joined the bureau to, what was it? "To enforce the laws of my country and protect her interests"?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You crashed my file?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: No. I consulted it. We're going into Indian Country, I wanna know what kind of individual is covering my ass. Don't you?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You've been in the bureau for thirty years. You survived The Hoov, the Black Panthers and Abscam. I don't see any bullet holes. That's good enough for me.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Who found him?

Speaker: miles
Dialogue: Indian kids. Hunting fossils.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Okay. I think Agent Levoi and I can proceed from here. What are your call signals?

Speaker: sherman
Dialogue: PX-10 and 11. Anything we can do to help you out, just radio.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Good. Thanks, Guys.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Leo Fast Elk... Thirty seven... single... Member of the Tribal Council.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Looks like Fast Elk wasn't fast enough to outrun that load. What do you make of the damage?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: That's what it looks like, doesn't it? But that's what a ten gauge, choke-bored, shotgun will look like when it hits your lower back from five feet away.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Somebody was serious about doing this guy, that's for sure.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Ray.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Taking ol' Leo somewhere?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Leo's been out here too long, man. I'm taking him to ceremonial burial.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: This is a restricted area.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Check him out, Ray.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Nice piece. You come back here to cover your tracks, Geronimo? What's your name?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: It ain't Geronimo.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: I think maybe you guys got off the wrong exit, yeah? This is the Bear Creek Indian Reservation.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: I know where I am. I'm on federal land, doing a federal investigation, and if you don't wanna cooperate you can take a ride in a federal car, and spend the rest of the day in a little room, answering federal questions. It's your call. Who are you?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: I'm a full blood Oglala Sioux, born and raised on this reservation.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: You're a wise-ass. Ray check his wallet.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I did.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Who the fuck is he?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: -- a fucking cop.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Walter Crow Horse. Tribal Police.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: He's a fucking cop.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: We got the wire ya was comin'. You're the Indian official, yeah?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: No. No, that's Ray, here. Ray, uh...  Ray... Little Weasel.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Leo's gotta get to burial, Brother. He's gotta make the journey.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: What journey?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Tell him, Ray.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Leo has to take the journey, Cooch.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: We'll have to give Leo a refund. Because he's gotta go to the M.E. In case you don't know, Officer, violation of the Major Crimes Act on --

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: -- an Indian Reservation is within the jurisdiction of the Federal Bureau of Intimidation. I know that.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Good. Thank you.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: I said when can Leo be taken to ceremony?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: After we've completed our investigation.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: That's a nice suit.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Somebody must be doing something somewhere in your jurisdiction, Officer Crow Foot.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You ain't gonna cut his hands off and send 'em to Washinton, are ya? They done that to one of our girls once. Leo did quillwork, he's gonna need his hands.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Leo's gonna need his hands, Cooch. He does quillwork.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: I think Leo's retired from quillwork for the moment.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Respect the dead, Hoss. Because when --

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: -- did you understand me when I said that --

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: -- violation of the Major Crimes Act on an Indian Reservation is within the jurisdiction of the Federal Bureau of Instigation. I know that.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Goodbye.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: What the hell you doing?!

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: His mother needs a piece of his hair. It's for the Keeping of the Souls Ceremony.  Has to be kept for four days.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Keeping of the souls. Do they still burn their dead or something?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Beats the hell outta me.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Sorry, Ray. You're gonna have to wait in the car. I'll bring you out a cheeseburger.

Speaker: clear moon
Dialogue: You made it. Was-te.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: You must be... President Clear Bone.

Speaker: clear moon
Dialogue: Clear Moon.  Moon. You must be the Sioux.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: No. That's Ray here. Ray...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Ray Levoi, Sir. Pleasure.

Speaker: clear moon
Dialogue: It's about time they sent us one of our own. Was-te.

Speaker: clear moon
Dialogue: Things are no good here. It is like war zone. We need an official who understands what is good for the Indian people. Who knows Indian way.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I thought we were staying on the reservation.

Speaker: clear moon
Dialogue: Yes. Rooms thirteen and fourteen are on Indian land.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: clear moon
Dialogue: Are you hungry? I have some nice raw kidney in the truck.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Oh, I'm set, Sir. I'm set.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: He's starving, Mr. Clear Moon. Get him some raw kidney. He hasn't had any Indian food in days...

Speaker: white local
Dialogue: Where you goin'? Back to the res?

Speaker: white local
Dialogue: What ya doin'? You drunk?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Let's take a walk.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: What's goin' on here?  I can't walk across the goddamn street without some breed-ass fallin' all over me?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Watch out now, he wants a kiss, Ray, wants a kiss --

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Go ahead, skin, get your ass back on your sacred land. Get outta here.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Get outta here. Drive.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: So what type of salesmen are you gentlemen anyway?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Liquor. We heard they like their drink on the reservation, and we were gonna see if we couldn't unload some surplus on the way to Nebraska.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Now keep that between us, Dennis, cuz I don't know what kinda Johnny Law they got here.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: Hey, Brooks, come over here. I want you to meet a coupla fellas from Denver.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: Liquor salesmen. Be nice to them, maybe they'll give you a sample of some of that gin you like.  He likes that Russian shit that --

Speaker: brooks
Dialogue: They ain't liquor salesmen. They're FBI.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Brooks, what's a perceptive fellow like you, doing in a joint like this? Let me buy you a glass of some of that Russian shit you like.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: FBI? What you investigatin'?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: A murder. On the reservation.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: Again. Figures, man.

Speaker: brooks
Dialogue: You'll never find out who did it.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: You underestimate me, Brooks.

Speaker: brooks
Dialogue: No. You underestimate these grass niggers. They're killing each other. That's all they do. Get drunk and kill each other. Then cover for each other. Who gives a damn really as long as they stay on their reservation. You ask me, the government shouldn't care one particle.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: You know how in your big cities, you got your niggers and you got your Puerto Ricans? Well out here we got Indians. That's just the way it is.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: The only good Indian is a dead Indian, does that old adage still hold true out here?

Speaker: brooks
Dialogue: That set-to you saw out front, was nothin' more than a message we were sendin' to the sonsabitches that are divertin' water from the river.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: We got rights. We got a ranch just up here.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Did any of you gentlemen know Leo Fast Elk?

Speaker: brooks
Dialogue: You fellas are here to investigate a Indian crime, you should keep to Indian land, and talk to them, not us. But you wanna drink here and shoot stick here, that's your right, and we respect that.  Come on, Son, we're up on the table.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: You fellas wanna play doubles?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Water. Worth killing for out here, I'd think.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Get the plate numbers off everyone of these cars.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I already did.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Couldn't sleep.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: recorder
Dialogue: -- out here we got our Indians. And that's the way it is.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: By the time you get to the main village, sun'll be up. I want you to fraternize. Socialize. Penetrate. Infiltrate. Eat some raw kidney, and get these Indians talking. I'm gonna Powwow with Big Chief Clear Moon and find out more about Leo.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Done.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Hobert Standing-Buffalo-That-Walks- Dreamer.  Hello, I'm looking for Hobert Standing- Buffalo-That-Walks... Dreamer.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Good morning. I'm looking for Hobert- Buffalo-Dreaming...  Hobert Standing-Buffalo-That-Walks--

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: --Dreamer.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Sir?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Ray Little Weasel. FBI. I like the way ya sneaked up on me. Must be Indian.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What are you --

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Watch out!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What?!

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You're steppin' on sign.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Hey.  Hey, you, listen up --

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: -- Leo wasn't killed here. He was dumped here. Out of a vehicle. Bald tread. Muffler held on with baling wire.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: The man you want... stepped outta the car, dragged Leo out, laid him down. Then walked over here and made a circle in the earth with a stick. I can't find the stick. He stuck an eagle plume in the circle, got back in his car, dustin' his own prints with a pine bough for about six feet, but he missed a print, right here, see. He got in his car and went Hell- bent-for-Holy-Sunday outta here. He ditched that pine bough three miles across the flat, in the Little Bear River, it floated down to Thundershield Gap. The car hit paved road, and was outta here.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: The killin' was done where Leo's mother lives. But he was driven here into these Badlands.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Big sonuvabuck. Based on the depth of that print, pressure releases... I'd say he goes two-ten, two-fifteen --

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Bullshit.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: -- Well, maybe two-seventeen.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You're trying to tell me you can read all that from a track?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: No. Not just a track. You gotta listen to the trees, man. To the leaves. To this sand, you FBI's kicked all up. You gotta listen to the earth.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Is that right? Well, listen to this: drag your ass. This is a restricted area.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: No, this is the home of the Oglala Sioux and I want the dog-fucker who killed Leo. Whether you get him or I get him, I just want him. Shit's been goin' on too long.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You've got no jurisdiction.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You got no know-how. About Indian Way. Or about Jack Shit for that matter.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Maybe you're not aware of this, Crow Horse, but I just flew in from a place called the Twentieth Century where we have such things as electrostatic tracking methods, psycholingusitics, DNA fingerprinting; I don't have to crawl around with the scorpions and talk to the fucking trees to get answers. Leo was killed right here.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Go back to the M.E., take a look inside Leo's exit wounds and tell me how chicken feed got in there. Trust me, there ain't chickens in the Badlands. His mother's place is --

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: -- his mother never lived here. She was from up in North Dakota.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: I'm talkin' his spiritual mother. Maisy Blue Legs.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: His spiritual mother...

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: To us Indians, our spiritual relatives are as close as family. I've got seven mothers on this reservation. Sisters. Brothers. You ain't one of them.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Thank God. Now listen to me, asshole. I'm giving you a break. But if my partner finds out you're here, you're gonna be reading rat tracks in Sioux Falls Maximum Security.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Easy. Easy... I'm goin'.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You weigh one sixty-three, yeah? Not a beer drinker. You're one of these tofu and pilaf characters. Pack your gun, under your coat -- left shoulder. But you got backup; a little .32, .38 maybe, in a ankle holster that gives you a right foot drag, Shoes are too tight at the toe but, man, they look cool. And that's what counts.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Crow Horse.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Fuck you.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Mrs... Blue Legs? Can I ask you a few questions --

Speaker: maisy
Dialogue: -- go away. Leave us alone...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Ma'am, Please --

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Mrs. Blue Legs. I'm Indian.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I'm Sioux.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Yeah, right.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Shit. Mrs. Blue Legs! It's okay!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Black Tail District, X22. You ready for this? Leo wasn't killed in the Badlands. I... I found the location.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Maisy Blue Legs place?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: How'd you know?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: I got one up on ya.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Go ahead.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: I've got the doer. I know who he is.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Meet me at base. Over.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Cooch. You're my hero.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Who is he?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: One of the leaders of the Warriors of All Red Nations. Militant organization.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: White eagle feather through the circle. That's their symbol.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: They obviously wanted it to be known that they offed Leo. Some kind of statement.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Jimmy Looks Twice put Leo's head through a glass door of the tribal offices three months ago. And threatened him several times since. President Clear Moon and the regional FBI feel he made good on that threat.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I'd just like five minutes alone with the motherfucker who hung that flag upside down.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Easy, Cowboy. No vendettas on my ship. Now: remember what I told you about Nam? Watch the grass, watch the trees, watch the shit house, be on your toes, and if we get committed, don't hesitate to empty that sucker.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Alright. Alright.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: It's show time.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What the hell is that?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: On the ground.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: This is the FBI! Come on out of there nice and slow. Let's move it! Hands on your head!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Hands on your head, Sir. Come on, come on...

Speaker: looks twice
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: James Looks Twice?

Speaker: looks twice
Dialogue: That's right. What are you doing here? This is a religious ceremony you're desecrating.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: We're FBI, James. We just need to ask you a few questions.

Speaker: looks twice
Dialogue: We are in the middle of a sweat lodge ceremony. Do you drag people out of your churches when they're in the middle of prayer?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Let's take a walk, Jimmy. Come on.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Go ahead. You can all go home.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: We just wanna take a look around your place, Jimmy. We're not here to bust your balls.

Speaker: looks twice
Dialogue: What's this about?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Your good friend Leo Fast Elk.

Speaker: looks twice
Dialogue: You think I killed him? Cuz he was an apple? Well, let me tell you something about Leo, Man --

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: -- don't "man" me, Jimmy. Where's the key?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Ray, use the federal master key.

Speaker: looks twice
Dialogue: No. Don't do that. Don't deface the property, man. The key's in there.

Speaker: looks twice
Dialogue: Inside... in the coffee can.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: There's no coffee can in --

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Jesus... Jesus...

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Get him...

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Assault on federal officers. Suspect has left the area. One officer down. Issue a Fugitive Alert immediately. Over.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Has the officer been shot, X-22?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: No, the officer's been bitten by a fucking badger, okay? Get a Fugitive Alert fucking now! Over.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You're an easy man to track, Ray. Ya walk like a penguin with a hard-on.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Is that right? What are the trees saying today?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: They're sayin' that nobody's gonna talk to you cuz they don't give away one of their own. But they did say there's somebody way across the Little Walking River who wants to talk to you.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: He sent me to find ya. He says he's got information.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Let's go.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Grandpa Samuel Reaches. Heavy duty medicine.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Medicine. As in medicine man?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Why does he wanna see me?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Good question. Hardly sees anybody anymore. Hasn't left this place in twenty years. Did you bring some tobacco?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: When you go see an elder, you always bring some tobacco as a gift.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What did he say?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: He wants to know if you ever watch the Cookie Monster. He says the Cookie Monster is not to be trusted -- a trickster.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: He says there's something wrong with Big Bird -- he's crazy,  He says you stopped the Inipi ceremony last night...?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: But he is not unhappy with you because he knows you.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: He knows me?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: He says he saw you in a vision some time ago.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: I guess he had this vision some time ago, in the Moon of the Popping Trees -- uh, back in the winter. He says you come from Wasi'cu city in the East but that your people... way back... are of the Minniconjou Sioux. But you yourself don't know that.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: He says he knew you'd be coming to Bear Creek. He was told. It is the will of Tunkasilia -- the grandfather that you come here. He says let's smoke the caanunpa the sacred pipe, symbol of truth. So that there will be no lies between us.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What's he smoke in that?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Sacred herbs. Tobacco. Don't worry, we don't smoke no Mexican agriculture in The Pipe. That's a white man's myth. This is a sacrament.

Speaker: grandpa
Dialogue: Mltaku Oyasin.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You don't smoke with him, it means you're hiding something.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: He says Wakan. Sacred. Five hundred year old turtleshell rattle, passed down from the Grandfathers. Heavy duty.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: He says, it is good. The Spirits are here. The Spirits want to know what you're doing here?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Tell him I'm trying to find the man who murdered Leo Fast Elk. Ask him if he knows where he is.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What did he say?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: He said he doesn't know.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: He just did the Gettysburg Address in Sioux. What did he say?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Uh... Grandpa likes to trade; no one stops by here without gettin' stuck in the old Indian barter. He, uh... he likes your shades.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What was he saying?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Why should I tell you.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Because he was talking to me.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Does he know something?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: The old man saw an owl. Over there in the dry wash. Last week.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: And...

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: He saw an owl.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: So what?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: The owl is a messenger. When one shows itself to a Sioux... it means someone's gonna die. The owl told him about Leo.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: The owl told him about Leo. That's incredible. I guess we just broke the back of this investigation, didn't we? Evidence doesn't get any harder than that -- not for my money. Is there anyway we can seduce this owl into Federal Court?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: He also said "listen to the water."

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Listen to the water. Listen to the owl. He also said, don't trust the fucking Cookie Monster.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Go back to your DNA finger-printin'.

Speaker: caller
Dialogue: Was-te Yelo! Let's have five more veterans. Five more veterans. Hoka Hey!

Speaker: chasing hawk
Dialogue: What is that that you honor there, uncles? After all the Wasi'cu country has done to you, after all he still does to you, you honor that flag?! That flag has been desecrated by the United States, because they have not honored what that flag represents!

Speaker: miles
Dialogue: Okay. Here we go.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Who's this guy?

Speaker: sherman
Dialogue: Anderson Chasing Hawk. Second in command behind Jimmy.

Speaker: sherman
Dialogue: Magedelana Eagle Bear. Eagle's claws and a bear's balls.

Speaker: miles
Dialogue: She keeps an AR-15 assault rifle in her truck. And she'll use it.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Mr. Clear Moon.

Speaker: clear moon
Dialogue: Our police are afraid of them. Please get them out of here.

Speaker: clear moon
Dialogue: They're going to kill me next. That's what I hear. These new Indians are destroying everything. Our people are a quiet people.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: They can lead us to Jimmy. Just let them go. We're tightening the net on him. We know he's on the reservation.

Speaker: clear moon
Dialogue: Help us.

Speaker: agent sherman
Dialogue: Where's Jimmy? We thought he'd be dancing today.

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: Are you the Washington Redskin?

Speaker: agent miles
Dialogue: Say hello to Richard Yellow Bird, Ray.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Ray, get to Jimmy's place and keep it tight. I'm gonna get a tail on his Warriors.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Go ahead, Ray.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I have a pick-up truck. No plates. Subject -- Indian -- entering suspect's house. Over.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Okay, Ray. I'm coming in. If he starts to leave the area, move in. And hold him. Over.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: FBI, freeze, Motherfucker -- drop it, drop it!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Turn around, put your hands on the roof of the truck.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: You're the Indian FBI.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: That's right. Turn around.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: The people are glad they sent you. They usually send in guys who come at ya with highbeams, screamin' "drop it, Motherfucker", stick a gun in your face, frisk ya down. Even if ya got a child with ya. No, it's good to have ya. It's gonna be was-te times on the res.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: I was gonna warn ya about messin' with somebody's medicine bundle but I forgot you know all about that stuff.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: This Jimmy's?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: You're not gonna catch him. He can shape-shift into different animals. Bear. Elk. Porcupine.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Is that like an hereditary thing, Magdelana, or can one take classes?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Jimmy didn't kill Leo. Why do you wanna do this?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: He tried to kill him twice before. That's a good place to start don't ya think? Leo was on the other side, wasn't he?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: -- Leo was an apple, that's right. Red on the outside, white on the inside. And Jimmy hated him. Kicked his ass a coupla times. But he didn't kill him.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Who did?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: You're the FBI. That's your job, isn't it? Ya know how many of our Warrior brothers got killed out here? I never saw any investigating then. Why now? What's going down here?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: A Fugitive Alert for a murder suspect. Before somebody else gets a shotgun blast in the spine.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Try the Fort Laramie Treaty. All over again.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Look. You and I can stand here in a culture clash til the sun comes up, talking about what's right and what's wrong. You're from the reservation. It's a different world.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: I'm from Minneapolis. Fifth Street. I did four years at Dartmouth before I ever set foot on this res. So I know about the other world, Ray.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Are you gonna keep that medicine bundle or are you gonna respect its power?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: When you see Jimmy, tell him the sooner he turns himself back into a human being and gives himself in... the sooner we back off this reservation. Okay?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Grandpa Reaches says you come from heavy Indian blood. I used to think Grandpa was gettin' senile. Now I know he is.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Move it, Magdelana.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Ray, you alright?

Speaker: agent sherman
Dialogue: What do we got, Ray?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: It was just Eagle Bear. I questioned and released her.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: What'd she say?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: She talks a lot of shit. We're not doing our job. Jimmy's innocent. "What's the FBI really doing here." Some shit about the Fort Laramie Treaty.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: She took something from the house. What she called a medicine bundle. Most likely Jimmy's.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Let's see it.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I gave it back to her.

Speaker: agent sherman
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: If it is Jimmy's, she's taking it to him. We'll have a runner. But I borrowed a little mojo...

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Way to go, Raymond. Miles, take that to lab. Sherman, I want you to go back to base and produce some written material. Something that indicates that our girl Maggie is leaking information to us. And make sure that material finds its way into the hands of the Warrior Movement.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: You gentlemen missed that medicine basket. Go back through the house, and make sure you missed nothing else. And lay some wire, too. Let's do it.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: That's good goddamn work, Ray. Let the salmon run. Let 'em run Upriver.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Why we setting Eagle Bear up as an informant?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Her own people start to suspect her, it creates discord from within. The Warriors don't know who to trust, they start infighting, and Jimmy loses his support.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Her oil pan is shot.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Cooch. What's the Fort Laramie Treaty?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Jesus, I don't know. You tell me. You're the Indian.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Get a tail on her, Ray.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Cooch.  Where the fuck did they send us?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: A long way from home. You be careful out there.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: For all I know, you're Jimmy. And you're just waiting for a shot at my jugular. Drink, Jimmy. Milk is good for you --

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Don't be mad. That was just an old traditional gesture that means hello, how are you.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I see. Forgive my cultural ignorance.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Have a nice day.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Jimmy didn't do it, Ray. I checked it out. You can stop taggin' my sister.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: She's your sister?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Gotchya. We just nailed a genetic match between the eagle feather left at the murder site and one in Jimmy's medicine bundle. It came from a white eagle. Same bird.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: So did this one. Wambli is a rare and sacred creature. When someone finds a dead one, the feathers get around the res. We share everything. A lot of power in the eagle feathers. But you think that's bullshit too, don't --

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Electromagnetic printing.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Was-te. 'Cept for one thing. Jimmy Looks Twice was nowhere near there. Ya see, when Jimmy was twelve years old, his mother and father was killed in a car wreck right down there near Elk Mountain.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I don't see the connection.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: The connection is, it did a head number on him. He's petrified of cars. Won't drive. I've known him all my life, and he's never gotten behind the wheel of a vehicle. He rides passenger and he rides horses, and that's it. The man that shot Leo down was behind the wheel of a moving car.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: That's not solid.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You want solid? That one, single, print he left in the Badlands -- the one the FBI missed and then stepped all over -- it belongs to a man who walks heels first. Like a white man. Jimmy has a serious Ind'n walk -- ball of the foot first. The man who murdered Leo walked like a Wasi'cu.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You're saying a white guy did it...

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: When Leo was dumped out there in the Badlands, he was dropped on his back. Our man made an effort to turn him over, onto his face. It's an old Ind'n belief that if a dead man is turned face down, his spirit won't leave. And in the killer's case, it won't come back and jump all over his shit. That's an Ind'n thing a white man wouldn't know.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: And that's the way it is. Write it down.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You laugh all you want, Breed. Sunset tonight, I get my man.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Alright, Crow Horse. I'm listening. I'm listening to the trees, to the stones. Who is it?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Damned if I know.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: But the Old One. He did a Yuwipi ceremony last night.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: The old man? He's gonna tell you who killed Leo?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Go catch Jimmy, Ray. Really. He's gettin' away. Go ahead, go get him. I'm late.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Hey. Hey, those are my sunglasses you're wearing.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Grandpa traded with me.  Goodbye.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: He says, back behind Red Deer Table, where the Elk-People-used-to-live... there are strange creatures from another world who eat stones... and who will kill anyone who crosses into this place.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: He says, in the Yuwipi ceremony last night, he saw you... going back into the land beyond Red Deer Table. I was with you. But that was all the Spirits let him see so he doesn't know if you were killed or not. But he thinks you probably were.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Go to the land where the Elk-People- used-to-live and you will find the answers you came here looking for. But you must go as two. That is the vision. I have spoken. And this is so.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: He wants to trade.  He likes your watch.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I can't do that,  It's a Rolex.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: A what?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I'm sorry, this is --  Tell him this is an expensive watch.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: He says, you need to go on Indian time. He says your watch is ruining your life anyway.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Red Deer Table, Ray.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Don't tell me: heavy duty.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Heavy, heavy duty. Taku Wakan. Wanagi Spirits. It's one of those few places we'd never go to as kids. Still don't. Some of the old people say Crazy Horse is buried back there. We have to go Ray. Together. Like his vision.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Walter. When I fill out my 302, do I say that evil spirits are killing everybody on the reservation?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Ray --

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: -- no. No offense to the old man. I appreciate you trying to help. But I put my ass on the line coming out here, man.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: What'd you expect to hear?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Not Native American myths and legends. I'm with the FBI, Walter, remember? Not National Geographic.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: What you call myths, we call our history.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: It's not real.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: What's real to you? Wall Street? Capital Hill? Now they are myths.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I can't be dicking around here. That's all I'm saying. I don't carry crystals, I don't wanna come back in another life. I just wanna do my job, and do it right, and get the fuck outta here.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You ain't no Indian. You're a Sal Mineo Indian.

Speaker: grandpa
Dialogue: Will ya knock it off? You're actin' like a couple of old women.

Speaker: grandpa
Dialogue: For cryin' out loud. Knock it off.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: He speaks English.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Only when he's really pissed off.

Speaker: grandpa
Dialogue: Come inside. Watch TV.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Don't accuse nothin' of not bein' real, Little Weasel. Cuz the only thing around here that ain't real is you.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Take care of yourself, Walter.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Likewise.

Speaker: sa sherman
Dialogue: We've gotten word that Jimmy has been trying to hook up with Maggie Eagle Bear... but some of the Warriors have been sending word to Jimmy that she may be an FBI operative. So he doesn't know where to go.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Bingo. It's working.

Speaker: sherman
Dialogue: He's out of room. All the reservation exits have been watchdogged. We got him. I give it twelve hours.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Well we better use those twelve hours to apprehend the right man.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: The right man? Talk to me, Ray.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Whoever dusted Leo, dusted him from the driver's seat of a moving car then drove those eight miles to the Badlands. Jimmy Looks Twice has never been behind the wheel of a car. It's a known fact out here that he's petrified of driving. His parents were killed in a car wreck.

Speaker: sherman
Dialogue: That's not very solid.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: There was also a print found in the Badlands that indicated diagetic locomotion. Heels first. Jimmy's walking pattern doesn't match. He has a distinct Indian walk.

Speaker: sa miles
Dialogue: Indian walk? You been smoking hooch in the peace pipe, Ray?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: They don't smoke hooch in The Pipe, Miles. They smoke something called kinickinick, it's like a tobacco.

Speaker: sa sherman
Dialogue: Well, you're right about X21 being a Washington Redskin, that's for sure. What else, Ray?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: You boys want a soda?

Speaker: sa miles
Dialogue: Oh, yeah, a Coke. You buying?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: No, Ray's buying. Sherman? Coke?

Speaker: sherman
Dialogue: Oh... no. No, Cooch, I'm working on a coffee here. Indian walk?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Genetic ditto on evidence found at the site with evidence you found in his belongings. An incontrovertible motive. And definite footprints on Jimmy Looks Twice at Maisy Blue Legs house.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: When did we get that?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Today. And now you -- there's a dog in the van --

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: -- I know. I fed it, and I can't get rid of --

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: You weren't sent here to go off on your own detail, Ray. You were sent here to assist in a Selective Operations Unit. These regional agents are inept -- that's why they were sent out here to The Graveyard, to Indian Country. I need you behind me, Ray. Not pulling against me.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I'm not trying to pull against you, Cooch. I've just been having nightmares about the way Leo was killed.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Your first homicide, that's gonna happen, Ray...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I just wanna make sure no one else gets done in that way because we were in bed with the wrong doer.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Ray. I never get into bed with somebody unless I know for sure. Just the way I was raised.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Alright. Alright...

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Yeah, alright, alright -- fuck you -- give a yuppie a badge and he wants to take over the world. Go get a tail on Eagle Bear, and stay with her. Cuz Jimmy's gonna show. And I want you to make the collar.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Ray.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: I'll sleep around a little.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Thanks, Cooch.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: And get rid of the dog.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Motherfucker.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Bastards...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: All I could think of was... not here. I don't wanna eat it on an Indian Reservation, three thousand miles from home.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: He's out there. He's out there playing Sitting Bull with us. I want the motherfucker so bad I'm getting a bleeding ulcer.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: It may have been Maggie's way of saying "get off my ass."

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: She's that subtle?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Eagle's claws and a bear's balls that's what her profile says.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Well, she's running now, too. These fucking people like to run, don't --

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: -- Cooch. Woh. Stop.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Tread matches. It's the car.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: But this doesn't make any sense, Ray. If it's just been sitting in this dry wash for seven days... why the hell didn't we find it?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Because this isn't a dry wash.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: It's the Little Walking River.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: And it was full of water when I drove by here three days ago. Full. I mean... a river.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: The Little Walking River. You're right. This is part of it. So whoever sunk this car didn't compensate for drought. Goddamn.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Listen to the water...

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Agent Little Weasel, Federal Bura of your Imagination.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Jesus Christ. You're hammered. What are you doing?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You're right about the old man. His power's long dried up. He's supposed to be a medicine man but he won't go see the people. He says we changed, and we don't listen. Well, he don't go out and talk no more. I haven't had a drink in three years but I just turned my sobriety chip into that man behind the bar, and this Hoss is gettin' watered.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Cut the shit. You shouldn't be in here, Man.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Cuz I'm a skin?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Cuz you're a cop.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Not no more.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You tell me. You tell me who went to the B.I.A. -- Bureau of Indian Annihilation and said I was messin' with your case, man. I don't give a goddamn about your case.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: And I don't give a goddamn about whether you wear a badge or not, Crow Horse, but I didn't cut you.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Still after Jimmy?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: They found prints at Blue Legs' place.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Yeah. Jimmy's prints are there. But they cross over Benjamin Black Star's prints. And he wasn't there until six o'clock the mornin' after to get eggs from the chickens. So Jimmy wasn't there til the next day. Follow?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Look, man... you better bust Jimmy and get out before somebody shoots up more than your car next time.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Next time I'll be ready. You get the word to who ever it is.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: I can't, Hoss. I don't talk to FBI's.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You think you was sent here cuz you're a good cop?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: No. I was sent here cuz I'm Indian. And a good cop.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You ever think that maybe you was sent here cuz the FBI's need one good reason to take out the entire Warrior Movement. And what better reason than one of their men, gettin' blown away on the res. A low-rent, expendable public servant sent in to take a bullet for his country.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I'm sick of your shit --

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Sorry, we don't speak United States.

Speaker: rancher's son
Dialogue: Yeah, well I do. Get the Jesus up, and get the Jesus out or I'm gonna go out to my truck and come back with my hardware.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Woh, hold on there, Jack, you're --

Speaker: rancher's son
Dialogue: -- don't "jack" me, Squanto. I'll bury your lazy ass right here.

Speaker: rancher's son
Dialogue: I'm talkin' to --

Speaker: brooks
Dialogue: No! No, you butt holes! He ain't skin! He AIN'T SKIN!

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Yeah he's In'dn. Miniconjou Sioux.

Speaker: rancher's son
Dialogue: You ain't Indian?

Speaker: older rancher
Dialogue: What's so damn funny?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Well, it's just that the cavalry used to always threaten the Lakota. The cavalry ain't around anymore. The Lakota still are.

Speaker: rancher's son
Dialogue: I got no trouble tellin' where you come from, Fat Red.

Speaker: bar man
Dialogue: Sorry. On the house.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: No plates. No registration. Serial numbers removed. And all prints washed off by the river. That's great. This is turning out to be a walk in the park, do you know that?

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Come back?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Never mind.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I read, Cooch.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Remember that upside down flag back at Jimmy's house? Somebody took it down.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: They took it down, set fire to it, and threw it on the doorstep of room 13 at the Buffalo Butte Motel. Your room.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: We traced the number of the truck that dumped it, and it belongs to one Maggie Sanders, also known as Maggie Eagle Bear. She's been all over the res, riling up the traditionals, telling them not to break, and to keep Jimmy in hiding. She's a problem now. And she's yours. Get her off the reservation.

Speaker: little girl
Dialogue: Are they all right under here?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Two-hundred and sixty-seven men, women, old people. And little ones like you. Many killed running along that road you see there.

Speaker: little boy
Dialogue: Where were they runnin' to?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: A place called The Stronghold.  They died for a dream. But you live. You are their great-great grandchildren and you live. We have to honor their dream. Of protecting the Mother Earth. And being proud of being Indian.

Speaker: little boy
Dialogue: My mother told me that they call us Indians cuz Columbus was lookin' for India when he discovered our country.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Yeah, well, let me tell you something, Henry: just be glad he wasn't looking for Turkey.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Richard. Sing the Honoring Song with them. I'll be right back.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: We're praying at the grave. Do you wanna join us?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: No, Maggie. But you're gonna have to join me for a ride. I'm taking you to Rapid City.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: So much power. I see it in your eyes. This... hunger for power. Or for what you think is power.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You burned an American flag today. And left it for me...

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: -- You desecrated it, it had to be burned.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I desecrated it?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: You forced an innocent man to run like an animal. You've tried to poison my people's hearts against me with your manipulation, with letters I never wrote... you've been watching me eat, work, raise my family... wash myself in the river. And now you're here, arresting me at a sacred place.  In your eyes, that's power.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: So I plant this tree for you. And I take all this stuff that you've laid on me and my people, and I put it in this hole with this pine cone.  And The Mother will turn your lies into something that lives.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: That's what power is, in the Indian way.  Take me to Rapid, Ray. I'm the enemy.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: If I told you... that I think Jimmy's innocent... but I'm in over my head... would you believe me?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: See those Black Hills out there, Ray? When the people lost the land in 1868, the government took everything but those hills. They allowed us to keep those Black Hills, to live there. Signed a treaty. Until they found gold. Then they told us we had to leave because of National interest. They broke that treaty. Anyone who fought or spoke out against it, wound up dead or in jail. And the people wound up here. On a reservation.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: While up there, in the Black Hills... they carved the faces of four presidents.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Your relatives must've taught you something.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: NO.  My father never told anybody he had Indian blood. But he still used a few Indian words around the house. He called me Washee. Said it meant... good boy.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Wa-shee is like... a dumpling. Like tallow we put in stew. I think he was calling you chubby boy.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Great.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You ever see that car before?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Who's it belong to?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Help me, Maggie...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I didn't see you today, Maggie.  Goodbye.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Goodbye... Wa-shee.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Anyone who fought or spoke out against it... wound up dead or in jail.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: That was 1868, Maggie...

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Jesus, you alright?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Yeah. I... I fell asleep. I can't believe it. I --

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Never turn your radio off! I thought I was gonna find you scalped! Damn it!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Sorry, Cooch. I lost Eagle Bear --

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: -- never mind Eagle Bear. We've got Jimmy nailed. Let's go!

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: HANDS ON YOUR HEAD!

Speaker: sherman
Dialogue: Where is he, Sam? Where's Jimmy?

Speaker: sherman
Dialogue: He's a medicine man, Ray. The "spiritual leader" of the Warriors. That right, Sam?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Trailer's clean, let's go.

Speaker: sherman
Dialogue: You been the one making it rain like that, out there, Sam?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Hey, put that down.

Speaker: sherman
Dialogue: Can you make Jimmy outrun an M-16, Sam?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Sherman!

Speaker: miles
Dialogue: EASY, MEN! HEY! --

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: HE'S ON THE ROOF! HE'S ON THE FUCKING ROOF! COME ON GUYS, COME ON, GUYS!

Speaker: looks twice
Dialogue: Brother, the old man told me about you. Listen to me: what was Leo trying to tell me? He wanted to meet me at Maisy --

Speaker: fed
Dialogue: Save your speeches for prison, Jimmy.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Damn. That's one hard running Indian.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: It's over, Ray. I aged five years. But it's over. At least I'm gonna look like I'm ready for the advisory desk. Let's go get a beer.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Look... I'm not who you think I am.  I'm sorry.

Speaker: grandpa
Dialogue: Out back that way... is a placed called Wounded Knee.

Speaker: grandpa
Dialogue: I was one years old there when our people were shot down. My mother hid me in the snow in a blanket. One of those killed was a Holy Man called Wakiyan Cante -- Thunder Heart. They killed him while he was running for The Stronghold. It is his blood -- the same blood that spilled on the grass and snow at Wounded Knee -- that runs through your heart like a buffalo.

Speaker: grandpa
Dialogue: Thunder Heart has come. Sent here to a troubled place to help his people. That's what I am told. Maybe you're right and I am mistaken. Your mind is young, mine is old. If so, so be it. Ho Hecetu Yelo. I'll speak no more.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Buffalo burgers and cold beer, Raymond. Don't worry about the sign out front... you don't have to be Indian anymore.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: You have a fever. You okay?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Listen: when we get back tomorrow, you're gonna find Tully laying a promotion on you. S.A.C. He wants to prove that his yuppie agents are making good. He's offering you New York. Tell him you want Atlanta.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Cuz I want New York.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Cooch. They sent us out here because the place was being neglected. Now, all of a sudden, there's two five man SWAT teams out there tonight. Bell Huey choppers flying all over the place. Federal occupation to catch one guy. Why, Cooch? What's going on?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: National security, Ray. Get some sleep. Tomorrow, we fly.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I'm looking for Richard Yellow Bird.

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: The Washington Redskin. Thought you'd be gone by now.

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: What ya want?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Must be a bitch getting around in that wheelchair. How long you been in it?

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: Since I got a iron pipe put across my knees, man. Fight with three wasi'cus, ya know.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: At Sioux Falls Pen?

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: No, that was Leavenworth. This --  was Sioux Falls. What ya want?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Leavenworth a tough joint?

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: You ever try solitary confinement?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: No. Can't say that I have, Richard. Richard do you know why I'm here?

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: Washington sent ya. I know that.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Yes, Washington sent me, Richard. They sent me here because this whole thing has been fucked. Do you know what I mean when I say this whole thing has been fucked, Richard?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: An arrangement was made between you... and us. Do you remember that arrangement?

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: I'm here, ain't I?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Not for long, Richard. You got early parole under the stipulation that you would help us in a situation, and you didn't deliver.

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: What the fuck you talkin' about?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Get up out of the chair, Richard.

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: What's with you people? Why do ya have to fuck with my head all the time? I came through, man.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Get up out of the chair, and walk toward the backdoor, Richard.

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: I get thrown in solitary until I don't know my own fuckin' name, and then you people tell me I can beat nine years if I help you. I helped you!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Get up!

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: They said I'd never see FBI again, and I'm livin' with you fuckers. I don't feed ya information on the Warriors, it's back to the pen. I don't do this, back to the pen. Your word against my word. Against a con Indian's word. I really got a chance, man, right?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: They sent me here, Richard because they said you didn't hold up your end of the arrangement, and I have to transport you back to Leavenworth.

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: What the fuck, man? What do you people want? I did what you wasi'cu's told me to do.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Leo Fast Elk... is alive.

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: No way. No fuckin' way.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: How the hell do you know?

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: I blew his back out with a buffalo gun, that's how I know! Now you're gonna say I didn't, so you can throw me back in solitary?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: The men who came to see you at Leavenworth. The one's who made the arrangement... who were they? Maybe I can talk to them.

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: Miles. Three other suits. That's all I know 'em as -- suits. Were you there?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You turned Leo over on his face. But the coyotes must've turned him back over, man, cuz his spirit is out. It's out, and it knows.

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: What do you know about spirits? You ain't no In'dn.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Leo knew something heavy and was trying to tell Jimmy. But you must not know how serious it was or you would have delivered. Do you realize what Leo could have told Jimmy?! Do you?!

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: I took him out before he got the chance. He didn't say nothin' about Tashka Sha. And now his spirit is in the dirt. Forever.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What's Tashka Sha, speak English, speak English!

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: Red Deer Table! What's with you, man?

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: Wait a minute. Wait -- what are you doin'? You ain't a FBI. You ain't the law. Let me see your --

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I'm the fucking law!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Keep talking, Yellow Bird...

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: All I know... is I did what I did... and I ain't in solitary, gettin' pumped up with downer, gettin' beat to shit. But I tell you what, Suit. Take me back. Cuz I can't take this shit no more.

Speaker: yellow bird
Dialogue: Man, I don't know who the fuck I am no more.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You and me both.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Maggie!

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Five-hundred year old turtleshell rattle...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Crow Horse, listen --

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Where's Maggie? Where'd ya take her.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Nowhere. I'm trying to find her.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You got Jimmy. Let her go.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Crow Horse, listen. You have to come with me.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Why? So you can get rid of me, too?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: No. So we can do what the old man said. Red Deer Table, Walter. We have to go.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Maybe the old man's visions are still strong.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Do they come in dreams, these visions?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Oh yeah. Dreams. Sometimes durin' sickness. Vision quest. Sweat Lodge. Ya never know when.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Just before we caught Jimmy... I had a dream that I was being chased. And I was running with other people. Old- fashion Indian people. I got shot in the back. Like Leo.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Where was this?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: At Wounded Knee. I mean, that's where I was, and that's where the dream was. Why?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You were running with the old ones. At The Knee. Heavy duty.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Well, it was just a dream, I --

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Sonuvabuck! What's with you, Man? Who are you?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Nothin'. Forget it.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You had a vision. You had yourself a vision. A man waits a long time for a vision. Might go his whole lifetime and never get one. And along comes some instant Indian with a Mastercard and brand-new shoes, has himself a vision.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: I'm a full-blood Oglala.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: We've driven a long way. Where is this place?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Maybe it was just a dream. Ya know, just one of them, what do ya call 'em, fitful dreams?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Yeah. Fitful dreams.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Bullshit. You had a vision. You got sign from the old ones.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What the hell do you want me to do?!

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Stop.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Ain't prayer flags, that's for sure.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Jesus. Oil?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Uranium. Test holes. Somebody came in from the Nebraska side, and did some shotgun testin'. They're gettin' ready to suck this baby dry.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: That's what we're doing here. National interest. National security. Only this time it's not gold. It's uranium.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: We're standin' on broken treaty ground, Ray. This ain't supposed to be here. It'll poison the water.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Leo knew about it. Tried to tell Jimmy, get the Warriors involved.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: So they took care of Leo.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Listen to the water... the river keeps goin' down then rising again.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: They're drainin' our water table. That's our life, man...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: No. No...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: This Clear Moon's house?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Yeah. It's time to beat the drum. You better wait here. He don't trust the white man.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Alright. Shit's comin' down. He's callin' council fire. All the old chiefs and the warriors, too. I gotta be at Grandpa's place in two hours. We need to get the tribe together. We need to block this thing.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What we need... is Richard Yellow Bird.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: I thought it was a rare case of a brother getting a break in the courts. We did an honorin' song for him and everything.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: He's looking at a few hundred years in Leavenworth. He's not gonna come out without a fight.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Ray. What's your 20?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Reservation.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: What are you doing on the reservation?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I'm on my way back in. Over.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Ray. Ray, don't let go now, Man. Ray...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You go to the council fire. I'm going back in.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Ray.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Ray!

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Couldn't sleep, Ray?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I had to finish something with Crow Horse.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: That's where you were. You had to go back and have it out with the Indian law...

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: You fucking hot head, we can get in trouble for that.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Why didn't you tell me what we were doing here?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: We're running a cover-up and you didn't --

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: You ever put your hands on me again and you'll be doing the books for a baitshop in the fucking Everglades, Mister.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You didn't tell me about Red Deer Table --

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: -- what the hell is Red Deer Table?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What is it? It's genocide, that's what it is. It's a Pay Zone for some U.S. corporation and a Dead Zone for the people here. Uranium, Cooch.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Jesus Christ. What are you doing? What the hell were you doing out there?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: This was a Selective Operations Unit, Agent Levoi. There is classified information pertaining to our national security. You don't question that, you don't go digging into that shit -- that's insubordination. Jesus Christ --

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: -- if they mine uranium there, these people will have no place left to go...

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: We were sworn in on the Constitution to protect federal matters, Ray. I don't know about uranium, I don't know about Red Dog Table -- all I know is we did our job. It's over.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: We neutralized anybody with a voice. Leo, Jimmy... Eagle Bear. Anyone who was standing in the way of the land. Is that it?

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: No. We neutralized enemies of the United States. Anti-American radicals who have killed federal officers out here!

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Jesus, Ray. You think I don't like the Indians? Not true. These were noble people but their day is gone. They're a conquered nation. They want all of America back but they can't even keep the garbage out of their own front yards. It's sad, Ray. But it's just the way it is. We have to function as a colonial police force out here.

Speaker: miles
Dialogue: You gentlemen ready -- hi, Ray.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Yeah, we're ready.

Speaker: clear moon
Dialogue: Ah, there you are. The Sioux.

Speaker: clear moon
Dialogue: You got the troublemakers off our land. Good, Was-te.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: RAY!

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: No, damn it. You call teams in and this is gonna be a fucking media event. Get me three cars, six agents, block all reservation exits. It's under control.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Crow Horse!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Crow Horse!

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Ain't no Council Fire, Brother. Clear Moon...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I know. Come on. We gotta get off the reservation or we're dead.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Hoka Hey. It's a good day to die.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Bullshit, let's get outta here,

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Grandpa...

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: X21, please read. Ray. Ray. X21, please read. This is Cooch. Please come in, Ray. Where are you?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: He's gone.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: He hasn't left this place in twenty years. They got him.

Speaker: miles
Dialogue: We have a renegade agent, Cooch? He gets off the reservation...

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: -- he's not getting off the reservation.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: They got us sealed. What are we gonna do?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: We're going for The Stronghold.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: This is President Clear Moon. This nation does not want your sympathy. You cannot use this reservation as a sanctuary. Stop where you are now.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Whatever you are trying to do is futile, Raymond. You have nothing. Nothing.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Yellow bird... is gonna sing.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Yellow Bird committed suicide at three o'clock this morning. Some gung-ho agent from D.C. pushed him into a corner. You're playing a losing game. Pull over.

Speaker: recorder
Dialogue: I blew his back out with a buffalo gun, that's how I know. And now you're gonna say I didn't and put me back in solitary?!

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: I could beat nine years if I helped you. I helped you!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Fuck you.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Walter.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: That's it. The Stronghold. Get us in there, we got a chance.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: We're in there. We're in there --

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: FREEZE! NOW!

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: DROP IT.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Crow Horse, get your face in the dirt. Ray... come forward. Let it go. Let's just let it go...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: No way, Cooch.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Ray. I'm coming to talk to you. I'm gonna walk you out of here. And we're gonna get the hell outta this place.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You're right, Cooch. It's over.

Speaker: chasing hawk
Dialogue: All the exits are blocked. There's two more fed cars tryin' to get in. And some press.

Speaker: cooch
Dialogue: Ray...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Let the press through.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: The people are already talkin' about their vote for a new tribal prez. They wanna vote for Jimmy.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What about the water...

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You bought her some time, Kola. Ain't never gonna be over... but you bought her some time.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Some Indian time?

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Indian time.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Where ya gonna go, Ray?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I'll have to see what the visions say about that one.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: You didn't have another vision...

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Yeah, right here.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You take care.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: If you ever need a place to come back to and listen to the trees a little... we'll be here.

Speaker: crow horse
Dialogue: Ain't no word in Sioux for goodbye.
